Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM - Collaborative Research: Universal Understanding of Push-Pull D-A compounds and Prescriptive Materials Design for Optimized Bulk-Heterojunction Photovoltaics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The sun represents the most abundant potential source of sustainable energy on earth. Solar cells that use organic conducting polymers to convert light to electricity - organic photovoltaic devices - offer a potentially low-cost route for renewable electricity production. In general, the low cost is offered through use of potentially inexpensive polymer materials and scalable polymer film based processing. However, current organic polymer solar cells currently suffer from low efficiencies combined with high material costs. Since improved materials are critical to commercial viability, the goal of this project is to develop and characterize more effective, low cost, sustainable, materials for organic photovoltaic devices. These new materials will be based on the squaraines, a class of organic dye materials. The key innovation of this effort is the development and use of theoretical modeling tools to screen for the best candidate molecules that optimize device performance characteristics. The candidate materials will then be synthesized using methods of green chemistry to enable low cost, sustainable materials that preserve the desired properties. The educational activities associated with this project will provide research participation opportunities for hearing-impaired students through the National Institute for the Deaf at the Rochester Institute of Technology.

Organic polymer-based photovoltaic (OPV) solar cells currently suffer from low efficiencies and high manufacturing costs, due in part to difficulties associated with attaining tight polymer morphology control. Higher efficiencies can be obtained with donor-acceptor type compounds designed to address bandgap and energy level requirements, if the molecular design rules can be realized from a first-principles perspective to optimize material properties for best device performance. Squaraines are class of organic photoconductors that offer several potential advantages as small band gap organic molecules for OPV devices, including ease of purification, scalable and consistent synthesis, and tunable functionality for prescriptive molecular design. This research will combine theory, materials synthesis, and critical property characterization studies to develop a fundamental framework for molecular design of donor-acceptor molecules in OPV devices based on squaraine compounds. The first objective is to develop and use theoretical models to simulate the morphology-based spectroscopy for a series of squaraines, compounds representative of the total set of done-acceptor type OPV targets. The theory will describe how morphological and molecular structure influences critical processes, including absorption spectrum, the excited states, and the intermolecular charge transfer integral. Thus, when the models are experimentally validated through spectroscopy, a more complete understanding of these processes will lead to a prescriptive design for idealized materials optimized at all critical properties needed for OPV, including solar spectrum absorption overlap, exciton diffusion, exciton dissociation, and charge transport. Based on the findings from the first objective, under the second objective, squaraines will be modified for processing in non-toxic solvents to enable low cost, sustainable, and scalable materials synthesis. Device fabrication and testing will confirm which critical OPV properties have been improved in these materials. Overall, this research is expected to lead to a more a comprehensive understanding of the excited state properties of squaraines, optimization of their critical properties for best OPV device performance based on rational molecular design, and scalable and sustainable methods for the synthesis of these materials and their integration into bulk heterojunction OPV devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Key Goals

The major goals of this work were to make simple push-pull donor materials for organic solar cells and to correlate their performance in organic solar cells with their crystal packing geometry, their mixing with fullerene acceptors, their spectroscopy, and the nature of their excited states as described with essential states modeling. In other words, by advancing the understanding of the structure-property relationship in representative solar cell materials we hope to prescribe how solar cells may be enhanced through the rational design of simple molecules that can be manufactured reproducibly in a one-pot synthesis and for which scale up and solvation in non-toxic ink vehicles is a logical next step.

Intellectual Merit.

New squaraines were manufactured, characterized and used in devices. The essential states model was expanded based on evolving descriptions of the excited states and was validated by simulating the spectroscopy of these new materials. Once the nature of the excited states was well understood, we looked to interpret device efficiencies and apply our conclusions to rationally develop novel materials and optimized molecular packing strategies.

The theory developed in a way that contrasted well-established exciton theory, leading to the explanation of an unusual type of red-shifted H-aggregate, driven by large quadrupole-quadrupole interactions in such materials. This photophysical description will continue to be used to better understand the impact of molecular packing on energy transfer, and therefore solar cell efficiency.

We subsequently measured an unexpectedly efficient energy transfer for H-aggregated molecules through ultrafast spectroscopy, with our spectra being simulated using evolving theoretical models. With knowledge of such efficient energy transfer in these aggregated molecules, and therefore predictably higher solar cell efficiency, other materials can be designed beyond these simple small molecules.

With theoretically-validated spectral characterization and a demonstrated control of molecular packing/mixing of the squaraine and fullerene molecules, we quantified the populations of three types of excited state, each one based on that mixing/packing. Atomic Force Microscopy data was used to support our spectroscopic interpretations. After correlating quantified excited state populations with device efficiency, we initiated a framework for tailoring molecular structure, and optimizing packing and donor-acceptor blend ratios to enhance efficiency.

All materials, theory, spectroscopy and approaches to device manufacture that were developed in this project for solar cells will benefit the entire field of optoelectronics and associated applications.

Broader Impacts

The broader impact was felt primarily through this enhanced understanding of a technologically important class of materials, stirring interest in wide application for low-cost organic electronics, for which the commercial impact will dramatically increase over the next few years, through products like flexible displays, electronic labels, solid-state lighting and solar cells. At RIT, this work was completed primarily by 2 successive PhD students, 5 Masters (MS) students and 10 UG students with various levels of contribution. Of all these students, seven were female, one was African American and one was Latina. Students developed knowledge/skills in synthesis and technology necessary for future energy considerations. They developed understanding in chemistry, materials science, theoretical modeling and device engineering that can be universally applied. Research experiences and publication opportunities for graduates and a large number of undergraduates were provided. Pedagogically, the theory and application of this work were incorporated into graduate courses, and into a middle school outreach activity each year. The research activities have substantially enhanced research infrastructure through evolving collaborations, in particular with faculty and students at primarily undergraduate universities such as Hamilton College, NY (Kristen Burson) and Appalachian State University, NC (Tonya Coffey).
